Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I gripped the steering wheel as my taxi crawled through the construction detour, orange cones squeezing the lanes to a single, narrow path. Up ahead, the yellow sign flashed: SCHOOL ZONE. Children clustered near the curb, their laughter and backpacks a reminder to slow down, to be vigilant. As a driver, I knew the rules—drive defensively, protect every life, especially here. But my mind tugged elsewhere. It was nearly noon, the time I usually paused for my daily puja. Today, I hadn’t managed more than a whispered mantra between fares, the full ritual lost to the rush of city streets. Guilt pressed on me; my faith asked for more than hurried words, for true devotion, not just habit. Yet, the road demanded my full attention now. My heart pounded with the weight of both roles—one calling for spiritual discipline, the other for unwavering focus on the world outside my windshield. I glanced at the children, then at the small idol on my dashboard, torn between the sacred and the immediate, unsure which duty to honor in this moment.
